The Library of Congress (LACMA) has acquired the cultural landmark photographs by Pablo Picasso from the artist’s estate under a long-standing, $6.5 million deal that will also see the latter placed on display in a three-dimensional installation at the National Museum of Fine Arts in Washington, DC.The deal is the largest gift made by the family of Pablo Picasso to the United States and will also include the creation of two new co-op accounts, one for the public and one for the artist. The estate will donate 1,500 prints and the original works, which were given to the institution by Picasso Sr. in memory of his son Pablo Picasso Jr., who passed away in 2008.The family also gave the institution 1,500 photographs, which were purchased for the institution’s acquisition in 1993 and 2003, and donated photographs of the works, which are currently on display in the artist’s workshop, in 2008 and 2009. The family also pledged $1 million for the acquisition of the works.
